title: Intro
description:
Hi, I'm Paul Doherty, a recent Computing Science graduate from Glasgow, Scotland. This website covers a variety of the projects I have worked on over the past years, from software development to entirely creative projects. Scroll through the wheel on the left to get a preview of each project and click into an item to read a detailed description.

 This site is still a work in progress, so please bear with me as I continue to add more content and polish the site. If you have any questions or would like to get in touch, please feel free to reach out.

content.value: Hi, I'm Paul Doherty, a Computing Science graduate from the University of Glasgow with a deep passion for building unique and memorable experiences. Whether it's hosting live events, producing creative content, or developing games, I love combining my technical background with a creative mindset to bring big ideas to life.

Game design, in particular, feels like the perfect intersection of everything I enjoy. It brings together art, storytelling, design, and technology, all skills which I have held a long-term passion for. From sketching concept art to crafting gameplay mechanics, every step of the process is an opportunity to express myself and connect with others in a meaningful way. 

I've been drawing since I was a kid, and that evolved into creating concept art, pixel sprites, and textures for my games. Later, I tried out 3D modelling and animation, a steep learning curve, but one that opened the door to building more ambitious 3D experiences. I'm also interested in level and gameplay design, where the challenge lies in crafting something that feels truly original. When it works, there's nothing quite like it.

This portfolio is a collection of the projects I've worked on over the past few years. While most are rooted in software and computing, others lean more toward creative expression. Altogether, they showcase my versatility in skills and show off the things I care most about, creating, problem solving, and sharing experiences that matter.

The logo featured on this site is one I designed when I was 15 in 2017. Originally it served as a logo for my YouTube channel but has developed into a symbol I use to represent my projects and creative work.

title: AR Flatpack Assembly
description: The project for my final year dissertation at university. This is a tool to help users assemble flatpack furniture without paper instructions using augmented reality on the Microsoft Hololens 2.

content.value: As my final year dissertation project for university, I designed and developed an augmented reality (AR) application, built on the Microsoft Hololens 2, which aimed to assist users in assembling flatpack furniture. The aim of the project was to determine the benefits of hands-free AR instructions over a traditional set of paper instructions.

To gain a background, a comprehensive literature review was carried out. This studied previous AR applications in industrial and consumer contexts. A gap was discovered for consumers where industries had taken advantage of AR capabilites. AR had been proven effective at providing instructions for workers in an indrustrial environment, yet this hadn't been experimented much with in a more general context.

An application was designed which would use the composite design pattern to translate steps to assemble a piece of furniture into an AR format. Two methods were created to demonstrate an instruction in AR: 
The first was by tracking real life objects using accurate 3D models and highlighting the location it should be placed while also informing the user if it had been placed correctly. This method would take advantage of
VisionLib
object tracking.
The second method was more simple. It animated a 3D model of the current part from one location to another, indicating the correct way to place a part.

(NOTE: Models lined up much better from the user's perspective than they do in the recorded demos)

This application was developed in Unity and built to the Hololens. Individual and accurate 3D models of every part of a piece of furniture had to be modelled using Blender. These were then set up as furniture parts in Unity which were ordered in the order they should be added within a piece of furniture. Each part came under a component and a component could either be a part of the furniture or the entire furniture itself. This meant that separate parts could be put together before being added to the furniture. For example, a drawer could be assembled by itself before being added to a bedside table. 

A few of the features relied on the VisionLib SDK. Parts could be tracked between real life and digital space as long as the camera could recognise an inital pose for the object. This was tricky to get right in context as the application was often used in cluttered spaces which led to the application struggling to keep track of parts. VisionLib also came with an inbuilt voice command feature. This meant that all user interaction with the application was done through voice. 

Some  pilot testing was carried out which concluded that the application needed some user experience improvements. Some features that were added to maximise the user friendliness were a view part command which gave users a close up, rotating view of the current part and an arrow that pointed to the current part when it exited the field of view.

A user study was carried out which split participants into 3 groups: paper, tracking, and animation. Each group assembled a bedside table using their given instructions. Any time a participant encountered an issue, it was noted and categorised. This was used to measure the effectiveness of each set of instructions. 

AR proved to be effective over paper instructions, especially the animated instructions. Participants tended to select the wrong parts and place parts wrong more while reading off paper whereas AR helped them to be more sure of what a part looked like and exactly how it should be placed. The object tracking method did not get used in its intended way very often as the tracking was just too unreliable. Otherwise, the biggest issue with the AR instructions was the learning curve. Users made most of their mistakes near the start of the process but towards the end, made significanly less. 

The project concluded that AR has some serious potential in improving the experience of assembling flatpack furniture. The lack of availability of hands-free AR currently is holding this back. An application which had improved object tracking a clear user guide to mitigate the learning curve would make for an excellent product.

title: Charity Football Match
description: Hosted a charity football match in memory of a close friend. Raised money and donations for a local foodbank. Gathered a live crowd but also developed a program to enhance a live broadcast/replay of the event.

content.value: In early 2024, I lost a very close friend. To honor his memory, my friends and I organized a charity 11-a-side football match in his name. We gathered a live audience, raised £4,910, and collected food donations for the local food bank.
Our team of four began with modest plans, but our ambitions grew as we realized our potential. We coordinated various aspects, including:

As a group we split all of the issues between us and came together every week to discuss progress and help each other out. To attract participants, we designed promotional posters and posted them online. We reached out to members of the local community which led to us securing a fantastic venue and coverage in local media. Read more about our story
here

To make the match accessible to those who couldn't attend, I developed a broadcast system resembling professional football coverage. Built using Python and integrated with OBS, the software tracked the match and overlaid dynamic graphics on the recording. 

It was a priority to keep the application from being too specific to this one match. To achieve this I set up a modular structure allowing users to configure 'Games', 'Teams' and 'Players'. A saving system was set up for each of these objects which means that users could even save a match in its exact state midway through.
I developed a user-friendly editorfor customizing teams. All information of a team could be changed and the players on a team can be managed from here.
The editor included a formation manager with drag-and-drop functionality, enabling users to set up complex formations which would be used in starting lineups for broadcast displays.

content.alt: The formation as shown in broadcast

content.value: Once a match was set up, the software connected with OBS using web sockets. A control panel allowed real-time management of game events—goals, cards, substitutions, and replays. The interface prioritized the clarity of information and maximum user control to ensure it could be operated live with minimal errors. Replay controls allowed moments such as goals being scored, to be revisited. At these points, footage would be split and the program would go automatically to the end of that clip to show a replay.

The match overlay displayed dynamic updates (e.g., goals, cards, substitutions) with custom animations. The animations were all manually implemented by moving item positions or updating a mask within a loop. A penalty shootout feature was even implemented for the case of a draw, but this feature was never required.

content.alt: The display at the start of a half

content.value: This application was fully capable of broadcasting the match live online. Unfortunately we did not have access to the required tech to connect multiple cameras to one device and I could not guarantee a reliable internet connection. This meant that the footage was prerecorded with one camera angle and uploaded later. In future I aim to have the match go out live in the likely event that we have another charity match next year.

I personally designed the badges and kits for both teams. The teams were inspired by two of our friend's favourite places: Malone's Irish Bar in Glasgow and Arthurlie FC's home ground, Dunterlie.

title: UI Strategy Game
description: Developed as part of a team project, this user interface focused game simulates an economy and allows you to enact policies and balance your budget to get the best results. Requirements for project were set by a customer

content.value:
Sunita was a team project developed during my time at university, created for a customer who set the requirements. The goal was to design a prototype that could eventually evolve into a full-fledged educational simulation game. The game challenges players to balance various economic variables by enacting policies and managing a budget. I was mainly responsible for developing the user interface (UI) and contributed significantly to the overall game design.

The core gameplay revolves around setting policies and allocating budgets, where each policy impacts specific variables and, subsequently, other interconnected elements. After setting their strategy, players advance through turns to see the outcomes of their decisions.

To support its educational purpose, we implemented a scenario save system. This feature allows users to create custom scenarios by defining variables and their dependencies through custom formulas. The system's design allows for challenges with diverse starting conditions to be created. The game's observer pattern architecture ensures that changes to one variable automatically update all dependent variables.

 Developed in Unity, this project marked the team's first experience with full-scale Unity development, a valuable learning opportunity that also came with unique challenges.

The development was carried out using agile methodology. It was broken up into sprints which concluded with customer review meetings. These meetings allowed us to provide updates on our progress and make sure our work aligned with their requirements. These were followed by scrum meetings in which we carried out retrospectives to ensure development stayed on track. When looking forward we created issues and used planning poker to assign them story points.

My primary role involved designing and developing the UI. This started with researching other user interface based strategy games. Using these as reference, each member of the team put together a wireframe and presented them. The best aspects from each design were agreed upon and I gathered them into a final wireframe.

I also took an important role in directing the team. I would regularly partake in peer programming as the navigator with other members. This led to many of my ideas making their way into the project. Much of the gameplay design for policies and variables affecting each other through formulas came from my ideas.

The final game appeared as follows:

The most significant challenge was learning Unity while developing a complex project. Learning how to master different aspects (UI systems, economic logic, and save/load functionality) within tight deadlines meant we had to scale back some planned features. The customer deemed this acceptable as they were only looking for a prototype. Focusing on extensibility ensured that the customer received a robust prototype with potential for future enhancements.
While the customer was pleased with the final product, we identified several areas for improvement:

content: The UI had minor visual and functional bugs.
The formula system for variable relationships was basic, limiting advanced interactions.

content.value: Despite these challenges, the project provided a realistic industry experience. It solidified my understanding of agile development, team collaboration, and Unity programming skills that have become foundational in my game development journey.

content.value: This is my Minecraft world which I started in 2015. I have worked on this over the years since, eventually coming to build 4 unique cities. The world is filled with details, lore, and easter eggs.
This is a very new project but one that has been on my mind for a long time. It is a tropical pirate haven named Chillis Island, which is also the location in
RAaEzo Man Battle.
Planet Coaster 2 is the perfect tool to build this world in with it's 3D building and terraforming capabilities.

A range of my creations in Cities Skylines 2. I enjoy creating custom maps that others can use themselves. My best custom map was a scaled down version of Glasgow and the West coast of Scotland created from scratch. This map received over 1000 downloads on
Paradox Mods.
